Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Smartphone Sensor for Crop Health Assessment and Reduction of Environmental Contamination
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to optimize and reduce agro-chemical and irrigation applications for the United States agricultural industry, reducing environmental contamination, and increasing overall crop health and production with a smart phone compatible miniaturized optical sensor. The diagnostic sensor, designed for use in the precision agriculture market sector, captures optical spectrographs of a plant that can be used to diagnose the overall health of the plant, and provide recommendations for optimizing care. In discerning whether a plant suffers from a nutrient deficiency, a water stress, or a disease pressure, the sensor provides a means for substantial commercial impact. By providing this market sector with the needed quantitative information to both specialize and optimize crop treatment plans, substantial agro-chemical and irrigation resources are saved. From a societal perspective, these commercial savings directly translate into reduced agro-chemical applications of crops, which help reduce eutrophication of environmental water bodies, protecting drinking water supplies. By optimizing irrigation usage, the sensor reduces irrigation demands, helping ensure the longevity of these sources of irrigation. By enabling big data analysis of optical spectrographs that correlate with underlying crop health conditions, the project provides insight into physiological factors governing crop health, advancing scientific understanding.

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is directed towards miniaturizing high precision optical spectrophotometers, traditionally confined to laboratory usage, for use in precision agriculture. The agricultural industry struggles to identify or anticipate changes in crop health and take appropriate measures of response. As multiple environmental stressors or factors can cause similar visual symptoms in a crop, optimal decision-making becomes decidedly difficult, and can lead to costly commercial and societal impacts. In response to this problem, this project aims to first develop a handheld smart phone-based spectrophotometer for real time diagnosis of crop health. Afterwards, the capabilities of the device will be extensively tested in controlled greenhouse studies of crops under varying nutrient and hydration conditions. Finally, the data collected in these studies will be analyzed and benchmarked against gold standard techniques of assessment. From these studies, the performance of the optical sensor will be clearly assessed. Specifically, the degree to which the sensor can discern amongst varying environmental stressors affecting a crop, and also the degree to which the sensor can provide quantitative feedback about the severity of those stressors, will be provided.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The STTR Phase I effort focused on developing a handheld, smartphone-based crop health sensor platform for quantitative detection of nutrient levels, water stress, and disease state in crops. The platform provides farmers with the ability to more effectively manage crop stressors and optimize agrochemical application and irrigation. This can save farmers money and increase their crop yields, while helping to reduce the impact of farming on our environment.   

The Phase I effort had two primary tasks: (1) develop a compact leaf sensor capable of performing measurements in the field, based on a previously developed miniature optical sensor system, and (2) evaluate field performance of the sensor during a series of studies to quantify nutrient and water stress levels in crops. Presented here is a summary of the efforts performed during the Phase I work.

1) Develop a compact and rugged, field deployable handheld leaf sensor:  The previously developed Atoptix miniature optical sensor design was modified with several changes to improve measurement performance and reliability for in-field use. In particular, the new prototype incorporates a patent pending, self-referenced optical sensor design and improved rugged case design for field use.

2) Field study and analytical model development: A series of experiments were constructed with several different crops in varying conditions of health located in both greenhouse and outdoor environments. Each experiment was completed generally by the following process; First, the handheld leaf sensor was used to capture several optical measurements of leaves of the crops. The collected measurements were stored on the smartphone during data collection, and then transferred to a computer for analysis. Next, the data was fed into machine learning-based models to identify various aspects of plant health, including presence of disease, nutrient deficiency, or water stress. For performing detailed analysis, Atoptix and Penn State University researchers developed and evaluated spectral signature classification models using machine learning algorithms. Results from the studies were very positive. For example, four-level quantification of nitrogen stress in maize was achieved with greater than 90% accuracy after training the model with true values of the nitrogen content in the plants. In water stressed rice trials, classification results indicate that our model is able to distinguish between well-watered and water-stressed plants with high classification accuracy.  Additionally, results from a citrus greenhouse study were analyzed and showed strong ability to clearly identify healthy from diseased trees, and distinguish trees with different diseases from one another.

These Phase I results help validate the handheld sensor platform for use as a plant health diagnostic in disease, nutrient, and water stress analysis, and present an exciting opportunity for the platform to be used for solutions with a broad impact on protecting overall U.S. and global food security through affordable, grower centered, fast optimization of crop health.
